title: Dinosaur Toolkit
description: The Dinosaur Toolkit was a project that leveraged SUE, the largest and most complete Tyrannosaurus rex specimen discovered, in an interactive learning environment.
overview:
The Learning Center at The Field Museum was developing a digital toolkit about dinosaurs and geologic time that educators across the country could use in the classroom. The problem space presented to us was extremely open, the only anchor to this project was that we had to incorporate the bone scans of SUE, the largest and best preserved T-Rex ever discovered. This was both extremely exciting and scary, as we only had about 9 weeks to complete the project.
Due to time constraints coupled with the open nature of the project, our designs weren't as fleshed out as we wanted them to be. However, our research and initial design ideas set the foundation in which The Field Museum can build upon.
details:
# Process We first conducted a competitive analysis to gain knowledge of what products are currently on the market and to get initial ideas for our own toolkit. We then did user research to get a more concise understanding of the basic requirements our interface. We went about this by talking with our client, creating a survey, and sending it out to a set of teachers that had previously been helpful in providing feedback to the museum about teaching toolkits. Additionally, we developed user personas and journeys to identify pain points in the teaching and learning experience for our users which will be addressed in our initial design of the toolkit.

# Research We conducted a survey with 8 educators from the Chicago area to learn basic demographic information as well as understand what teachers find exciting and what they think will lead to engagement of their students.

The survey helped us come to the conclusion that our target demographic is middle school students, and that we should aim to create a flexible web application that can be easily adapted to lesson plans with activities that can be done individually or in a group of students together.

![Primary Persona Jeff](/img/jeff-persona.png "Primary Persona Jeff") ![Primary Persona Gwen](/img/gwen-persona.png "Primary Persona Gwen") We created two personas meant to represent the two kinds of users of The Field Museum's toolkits. The personas were originally created using the qualitative responses of teachers from The Field Museum’s Biomechanics Toolkit survey.

![Jeff User Journey](/img/jeff-journey.jpg "Jeff User Journey")

![Gwen User Journey](/img/gwen-user-journey.jpg "Gwen User Journey")

To accompany these personas, we created user journeys to illustrate how each of the users may act and feel when completing an activity in the current state.

# Requirements From our research, we were able to come up with concrete requirements to help structure our project.

UX

  • Scalable solution using one or two dinosaurs.
  • Students can work together and share the device or work independently and have an equivalent experience.
  • Allow students to learn through exploration rather than direct instruction.

CONTENT

  • It should include activities that meet the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) learning objectives so that it is a viable solution for teachers to use as a tool to supplement lesson plans.
  • Activities must be flexible to easily adjust for a variety of lesson plans

TECHNICAL

  • Must be a web application.
  • Must be light enough to operate on hardware with low CPU capabilities.
  • Integration of Sketchfab platform.


# Ideation ![Ideation Sketch Dinosaur and Platforms](/img/dino-sketch.jpg "Ideation Sketch")
We began our ideation phase by sketching as many potential ideas for our web app as we could in 2 minutes, and then discussed what we had come up with. We had many ideas we liked, such as a “race through time” idea, where users saw how dinosaurs evolved into birds, or possibly a puzzle where students would piece Sue’s skeleton back together while getting to examine their bones’ functions more closely.
After coming up with all these ideas we quickly realized that our activities needed to be more closely related, as we were all across the board. We also knew that the activities had to relate to content that would actually be taught in the classroom, as we wanted the end product to be useful and relevant.
This is when we decided that we needed to be more focused on hitting points brought up by the NGSS. After examining the topics that NGSS aims to teach, we decided that the wanted our activities to focus on evolution and natural selection. We had another brainstorming session where we asked questions related to these topics. In addition to deciding what we wanted to teach, we knew that we also needed to create a place where any and all activities could be accessed. We came up with the idea to create a landing page with floating islands that link to multiple activities.
